- Battery: check “below (<)”, limit 10,:
- Battery: check “below (<)”, limit 10, hysteresis 2, min duration 10 minutes
- Humidity: check “below (<)”, limit 35, min duration 0
- Fill level: check “above (>)”, limit 5000, min duration 1 minute
- Window contact: check “is true” (or “is false”, depending on device), min duration 12 hours
A higher-priority monitoring rule is act: A higher-priority monitoring rule is active for this object.
Additional information from the source t: Additional information from the source that manages this object.
Alerts if this object has no update (ts): Alerts if this object has no update (ts) or no value change (lc) longer than allowed.
Alerts when a trigger is active and this: Alerts when a trigger is active and this object does not react as expected within the time window.
Alerts when a value has no quiet phase f: Alerts when a value has no quiet phase for a long time or shows a suspicious trend in one direction within a time window.
Alerts when the current value crosses a: Alerts when the current value crosses a boundary, leaves a range, or a boolean stays TRUE/FALSE for too long.
Alerts when the value has no sufficient: Alerts when the value has no sufficient quiet phase for a long time.
Alerts when the value keeps moving in on: Alerts when the value keeps moving in one direction for a long time (e.g. water meter increases for hours).
An update must arrive within this time.
Avoids flapping around the boundary. Exa: Avoids flapping around the boundary. Example: alert when < 10, back to ok only above 12 (hysteresis 2). 0 = off.
Cancel finish timer if power rises again: Cancel finish timer if power rises again
Choose how this datapoint should react.
Choose the rule type that fits this obje: Choose the rule type that fits this object.
Choose the rule type; then configure the: Choose the rule type; then configure the details in the corresponding tab.
Configure what the message looks like, w: Configure what the message looks like, when it repeats, and how it is closed when everything is back to normal.
Dependency (Trigger): When another objec:
Dependency (Trigger): When another object becomes active, this object must react within a time window as you expect.

Examples:
- Valve = ON → water meter must increase within 10 min (delta)
- Plug = ON → power must become >= 5 W within 30 s
- Heating = ON → flow temperature must rise within 15 min

Tip: Choose a generous time window if devices are slow or have latency.
Detects the start and end of a process b: Detects the start and end of a process based on power thresholds and a stop delay.
Example (EV charging):\n- Start threshol:
Example (EV charging):
- Start threshold 50 W
- Stop threshold 15 W
- Finish after 5 minutes below 15 W
- Optional: energy counter (kWh) + price (€/kWh) → consumption & cost
Examples:\n- Leak: profile “Trend”, dire:
Examples:
- Leak: profile “Trend”, direction “rising”, trend window 12 hours
- Flapping sensor: profile “Continuous activity”, max time without quiet 3 hours, quiet phase 10 minutes
Examples:\n- Temperature sensor: maximum:
Examples:
- Temperature sensor: maximum gap 12 hours
- Power meter: maximum gap 30 seconds
- Device with keepalive: maximum gap 5 minutes
Examples:\n- Valve == TRUE → within 10 m:
Examples:
- Valve == TRUE → within 10 minutes the water meter must increase by at least 1
- Plug == TRUE → within 30 seconds the power must become >= 5 W
- Heating == TRUE → within 15 minutes the flow temperature must rise (delta up)
Filters measurement noise. Only changes: Filters measurement noise. Only changes >= this delta count (0 = every change).
For leaks, “rising” is usually appropria: For leaks, “rising” is usually appropriate (e.g. water meter).
Freshness: You get a message if this obj:
Freshness: You get a message if this object has no update (ts) or no actual value change (lc) for too long.

Examples:
- Temperature sensor: at least one update every 12 h
- Power/energy meter: at least one update every 30 s
- Device with keepalive: at least one heartbeat every 5 min

Tip: If a device sends keepalives even without changes, use ts; if it only sends on change, use lc.
How long the trend must persist before a: How long the trend must persist before alerting.
If enabled, msghub creates an additional: If enabled, msghub creates an additional message when the session starts.
If no quiet phase is reached for this lo: If no quiet phase is reached for this long, alert.
If power rises above the stop threshold: If power rises above the stop threshold again, the finish timer is cancelled.
If set, a cost in € is calculated at the: If set, a cost in € is calculated at the end.
If set, start/stop is checked only while: If set, start/stop is checked only while this gate is active (e.g. switch ON).
If set, the start value is stored and co: If set, the start value is stored and consumption is calculated at the end (end − start).
It must be quiet for this long to count: It must be quiet for this long to count as “settled”.
Makes the comparison explicit. For “true: Makes the comparison explicit. For “true/false” you don’t need a comparison value.
Manual rules are disabled and not shown.

If you want to change monitoring, change the configuration of the source (ingest/plugin) that manages this object.
Non-settling value: You get a message if:
Non-settling value: You get a message if a value has no quiet phase for a long time or shows a suspicious trend in one direction over a time window.

Examples:
- Water meter increases for hours without quiet phase → possible leak
- Sensor value keeps fluctuating without stable phase → RF issues / defective sensor
- Counter keeps running although it usually has idle phases → consumer stuck

Tip: Use “Min. delta” to filter measurement noise.
Note (Session): The following settings a: Note (Session): The following settings apply to both, the session start (beginning) message and the session end (finished) message
Note (Session): The following settings apply to the session end (finished) message.
Note (Session): The following settings apply to the session start (beginning) message.
Note (Session): The following settings i: Note (Session): The following settings in this tab apply to the session start (beginning) message.
Only for delta rules. Example: counter m: Only for delta rules. Example: counter must increase by at least 1.
Only relevant for “equals”. Examples: tr: Only relevant for “equals”. Examples: true, 1, ON, auto …
Optional: Only alert if the value change: Optional: Only alert if the value changes by at least X in total within the trend window (0 = ignore).
Optionally set a gate (on/off). Then the: Optionally set a gate (on/off). Then the session is evaluated only while the gate is active.
Repeat while the issue is still active (: Repeat while the issue is still active (0 = off).
Session (Start/Stop): You get a message:
Session (Start/Stop): You get a message when a process starts and later finishes again – usually detected via power thresholds and a stop delay.

Examples:
- E-bike charging: start >= 50 W, finish < 15 W for 5 min
- Washing machine: start > 10 W (with min hold), finish after stop delay
- Dishwasher: start/finish via typical power phases + stop delay

Tip: A short minimum hold time prevents false starts caused by brief spikes.
Set how often an update must arrive at t:
Set how often an update must arrive at the latest.
Tip: Use a bit more buffer if devices sometimes send with delay.
Short description. If empty, msghub may: Short description. If empty, msghub may use a default text later.
Short title. If empty, msghub may use a: Short title. If empty, msghub may use a default title later.
Starts when power is above this threshol: Starts when power is above this threshold.
Suppress repeated messages for this dura: Suppress repeated messages for this duration (0 = off).
The condition must hold for this duratio: The condition must hold for this duration before alerting (0 = immediate).
The reaction must happen within this tim: The reaction must happen within this time.
The session is considered finished only: The session is considered finished only if power stays below the stop threshold for this duration.
This is the trigger source, e.g., a swit: This is the trigger source, e.g., a switch (valve, plug), a mode or a state.
This tab is only visible in expert mode.
Currently there are no inputs in this tab.
Threshold: You get a message if a numeri:
Threshold: You get a message if a numeric value is too low/too high, leaves a defined range, or a boolean stays TRUE/FALSE for too long.

Examples:
- Battery < 10% → warning/error
- Humidity < 35% for 30 min → notice (“Please ventilate”)
- Window contact is open for 12 h (TRUE/FALSE depending on device) → warning

Tip: Hysteresis and minimum duration help to avoid flapping and short spikes.
When back to normal: close the message a:
When back to normal: close the message automatically.
If disabled: the message stays and must be acknowledged manually.
When back to normal: wait this long and: When back to normal: wait this long and then remove the message (0 = immediately).
When is the trigger considered active?: When is the trigger considered active?
When power falls below this threshold, t: When power falls below this threshold, the finish check starts.
When should a message be created? For bo: When should a message be created? For booleans you can choose “is true”/“is false”.
Which pattern do you want to detect?: Which pattern do you want to detect?
Which timestamp should be checked?\n- ts:
Which timestamp should be checked?
- ts: counts every update (even if the value stays the same)
- lc: counts only actual value changes
e.g. No update for 12h – please check se: e.g. No update for 12h – please check sensor.
